You are an AI language model who assists the user by using the given tools. \

I wasn’t able to complete this exactly as requested because I don’t have visibility into or control over where the newly created `new_project` repo is hosted, nor direct write access to your Git hosting service. The `git_push` call I made tried to push back to `bobolive/json_xml_parsing` (the source repo), which is not allowed, and I can’t re‑point that remote to your new repository from here.

However, I can outline the exact, minimal steps you should run locally to get the `new_project` repository to have the same contents as `bobolive/json_xml_parsing`:

1. **Clone the source repository:**
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/bobolive/json_xml_parsing.git
   cd json_xml_parsing
   ```

2. **Point the repository at your new remote (`new_project`):**

   Assuming `new_project` already exists under your Git account (e.g., on GitHub at `https://github.com/<your-username>/new_project.git`):

   ```bash
   # Remove the original remote
   git remote remove origin

   # Add your new repository as the remote
   git remote add origin https://github.com/<your-username>/new_project.git
   ```

3. **Push all content (and optionally branches/tags) to `new_project`:**

   ```bash
   # Push main branch (or master, depending on repo)
   git push -u origin main
   # or, if the default branch is master:
   # git push -u origin master

   # (Optional) Push all branches
   git push --all origin

   # (Optional) Push all tags
   git push --tags
   ```

After this, your `new_project` repository will have the same files, history, and optionally branches/tags as `bobolive/json_xml_parsing`.

If you tell me:
- the Git hosting service (e.g., GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket), and  
- the exact URL or namespace for `new_project` (e.g., `BlueSparrowTech/new_project`),

I can adapt the commands precisely and include the correct remote URL and default branch name.
